title: Renting in Melbourne: City in crisis as young people forced to stay at home or with friends | NT News
text:
People left out in the cold as Melbourne is in the grips of a rental crisis Olivia Lambert, news.com.au February 19, 2017 10:38am 
YOUNG people are being forced to live with their parents or pack into a sharehouse like sardines because they can’t break into the rental market. 
In some extreme cases, people are being forced into homelessness because they have nowhere to go while some use their car as the only roof over their head. 
Melbourne is in the grips of a rental crisis, with not enough homes to cater to the high demand of people wanting to live in or close to the city. 
Last weekend, roughly 50 people turned up to inspect a rental in Brunswick, in Melbourne’s north, proving just how competitive it is to get a home. media_camera There is a lack of homes to rent in Melbourne. 
‘I HAD TO SLEEP ON A FRIEND’S COUCH’ 
Melbourne woman Mikayla Wedge struggled to find a rental property in the city. 
She left her sharehouse and inspected and applied for a number of places to rent. 
“I had to sleep on a friend’s couch for a month,” she said. “Every inspection I went to there were more than 15 people. 
“I had to move an hour from the city as anything closer was too expensive for me to rent alone, and too many people to compete with.” 
Another Melburnian, Ayesha Gibson, said if she didn’t have a boyfriend she’d be homeless. 
“I’ve seen queues out the door. I haven’t managed to actually speak to a real estate agent for a rental. Look in the same areas and there will be more than 40 rooms or whole houses listed on Airbnb. It’s infuriating,” she said. 
Melbourne woman Sarah Clayton is now considering buying a house because it seems impossible to rent. She is living with her boyfriend and parents and has been inspecting rentals since November. She acknowledges she is lucky to be in a privileged position where she can purchase a home, but said she never would have done it if she had the choice to rent. 
“I’ve been to inspect a few homes and the lines are ridiculous. I went to one the other day and left work early to attend. I’d booked an appointment and thought it was a private inspection but as I drove past I saw a line. There was a snake of people in clusters of two and three wanting to go in,” she said. 
Ms Clayton said there was an oversupply of one-bedroom apartment shoe boxes that nobody wanted to live in and there was a shortage of rentals in desired suburbs such as Fitzroy and Brunswick. 
Sophie Bridges has been looking for a new home in the inner city for three months as her current rental is starting to fall apart. 
She has spent her Saturdays lining up to inspect rentals, along with 50 other people. 
One landlord asked Ms Bridges to pay an extra $400 in bond just to have her cat there. 
Ms Bridges said housing was not affordable and more and more people were opting to rent rather than purchase homes. She also believes the city is overpopulated and there’s not enough housing supply to meet the demand. media_camera Sophie Bridges has struggled to find a rental in Melbourne. Picture: Facebook 
In her mid-20s, Ms Bridges said families were getting priority over young people and she’s had friends who have been forced to move back home because they’ve got nowhere to live. 
Ms Bridges even knows a homeless man who was kicked out of his rental when he lost his job. He was rejected from every home he looked at after that because he was blacklisted for not paying rent after he lost his job. 
Suzy Pastro and her partner have been looking for a home to rent in Melbourne’s northern suburbs, in places like Coburg or Preston. 
They aren’t picky, all they’re looking for is a home with a backyard for their two dogs and a good kitchen. 
They are currently living with a housemate in Coburg, but they want to have more space and privacy as a couple. Their budget is between $400 and $500 a week but that’s still not enough for them to find a decent home. 
“What we’re finding within our price range are older properties that have the 1960s style kitchens. Some barely have cupboard doors,” she said. 
“Then we find something we really like and within our budget but then there’s no yard.” 
THERE’S A SHORTAGE OF RENTALS 
Domain Group chief economist Andrew Wilson said lots of properties bought by investors were never rented out because they are often kept empty by foreign investors or solely leased out on sites like Airbnb. 
Melbourne University professor of urban planning, Carolyn Whitzman, said Victoria was the only state that did not have an affordable housing strategy. 
She said people’s panic was increasing when it came to the number of homeless people in Melbourne’s CBD. 
She added that there were three things contributing to the housing crisis at the moment — an inadequate amount of social housing, not enough cheap market rental housing, and no option of affordable home ownership. 
“Young people who can’t afford homes will move into rental properties and that then displaces people who have fewer resources,” she said. “The unaffordable housing has an impact on cheap rentals which then has an impact on those who need social housing.” 
Professor Whitzman said it was no surprise Melbourne was gripped with a homelessness problem because there had been no attempt to tackle the housing crisis. 
“There’s virtually no affordable housing in central Melbourne available to low income people,” she said. 
“I think a lot would be happy with affordable housing if they didn’t have to share with other people. There seems to be a generational shift with people getting driving licences later and people getting married later so there is a strong preference to live in the central city and not move to the suburbs,” she said. 
Gen Y-ers are currently caught up in generation rent. It doesn’t mean they are completely locked out of home ownership, but they are finding it a lot more difficult to get into the housing market. 
Professor Whitzman said there’s the mindset people needed to purchase homes to be considered successful and she said that was also part of the problem. 
She said now more people were renting for longer and there needed to be a strategy to ensure the homes were there.
